Allergy and Asthma Self-Study Module Tuesday, February 19, 2008 3:00 PM
[LIST_ITEM] ☐ Cytokines secreted increase production of IgE, IL-4, IL-13, IL-5
[LIST_ITEM] ☐ Cytokines mature eosinophils and influence allergic responses
[LIST_ITEM] Mediated by IgE binding to receptor on mast cells, basophils, activated eosinophils
[LIST_ITEM] Degranulation when allergen binds to IgE to release mediators of early phase responses w/in mins
[LIST_ITEM] Late phase mediators result in release of more inflammatory mediators hours to days later
[LIST_ITEM] Granules (mast cell) contain heparin, histamine, proteases, TNF-α, lipid mediators, cytokines, chemokines
[LIST_ITEM] ☐ Production in bone marrow enhanced by IL-5
[LIST_ITEM] ☐ Chemokines from Th2 cells chemotactic for eosinophils (presence is characteristic of chronic allergic inflammation)
[LIST_ITEM] Basophils - Stain w/ basic dyes, degranulated when binding IgE
[LIST_ITEM] Tend to be small, particulate proteins inhaled or exposed in small quantities
[LIST_ITEM] Can be used for benefits like vaccines or pathology of allergic responses
[LIST_ITEM] Pollens, food proteins, pet dander, dried feces of dust mites
[LIST_ITEM] Routes of exposure: airborne inhalation, contact, oral ingestion, medical injection
[LIST_ITEM] Atopic Individuals do not become allergic to proteins in vaccines
[LIST_ITEM] ☐ b/c these are encountered in different presentation, location, dose
[LIST_ITEM] ☐ Recognized by immune system to stimulate T cell memory and ultimately host protection
[LIST_ITEM] Genetically determined tendency to produce IgE mediated hypersensitivity rxns against innocuous substances
[LIST_ITEM] Significant genetic component w/ several genes involved
[LIST_ITEM] ☐ Latest genome wide screen for genes contributing to asthma revealed ten different loci on different chromosomes
[LIST_ITEM] ☐ 11q and 20p significantly associated w/ asthma even by most conservative tests
[LIST_ITEM] ☐ Several genes whose products regulate Th2/Th1 balance or regulate expression of IgE
seem to contribute to atopic diseases (IL-4 receptor α for example)
[LIST_ITEM] Observations that infants on farms tend to have less atopic disease than city dwellers or individuals from industrialized nations
[LIST_ITEM] Infants exposed to certain antigens may be less likely to develop allergies
[LIST_ITEM] Exposure to bacterial antigens critical to appropriate balance of Th1 and Th2 immune responses
[LIST_ITEM] Part of body exposed will display symptoms often
[LIST_ITEM] Response is usually in dose-dependent manner
[LIST_ITEM] Uticaria = hives caused by skin contact
[LIST_ITEM] Allergic response to breathed in allergen
[LIST_ITEM] Result of mast cell degranulation --> smooth muscle contraction
[LIST_ITEM] Recurrence of such problems during late phase
[LIST_ITEM] Increased secretion of mucus and fluids exacerbates problems in oxygen exchange
[LIST_ITEM] Causes most of the acute symptoms of allergic rxn
[LIST_ITEM] Due to chemokines, leukotrienes, cytokines synthesized by mast cells after IgE mediated activation by Th2 cells after restimulation by allergenic antigens
[LIST_ITEM] In asthma, late phase is more detrimental b/c it results in permanent lung damage
[LIST_ITEM] Some allergens in the blood stream can lead to degranulation of mast cells associated w/ blood vessels
[LIST_ITEM] Cascade causes systemic smooth muscle constriction and vascular permeability (anaphylactic shock)
[LIST_ITEM] Drug allergies, insect stings, and food can be associated w/ systemic anaphylactic shock
[LIST_ITEM] Treatment relies on EPI and medicines to restore normal cardiac and respiratory systems
[LIST_ITEM] Desensitization by injection of allergens in form that changes nature or intensity of
[LIST_ITEM] Inducing tolerance or shifting production of antibodies away from IgE
[LIST_ITEM] Usually used w/ aeroallergens and drugs, not foods
